data.code: An operator is a reserved word or a character used primarily in an SQL statement's WHERE clause to perform operation(s), such as comparisons and arithmetic operations.
SQL LIKE clause is used to compare a value to similar values.
SELECT FROM table_name WHERE SALARY LIKE '200%'
The UNION operator is used to combine the result-set of two or more SELECT statements.

data.subheading: UNION : Combine rows from two queries
data.code: SELECT c1, c2 FROM t1  UNION [ALL] SELECT c1, c2 FROM t2;
Used to combine two SELECT statements, but returns rows only from the first SELECT statement that are identical to a row in the second SELECT statement

data.subheading: INTERSECT: Return the intersection of two queries
data.code: SELECT c1, c2 FROM t1 INTERSECT SELECT c1, c2 FROM t2;
MINUS operator will return only those rows which are unique in only first SELECT query and not those rows which are common to both first and second SELECT queries.

data.subheading: MINUS: Subtract a result set from another result set
data.code: SELECT c1, c2 FROM t1 MINUS SELECT c1, c2 FROM t2;
SELECT c1, c2 FROM t1 WHERE c1 [NOT] LIKE pattern;
SELECT c1, c2 FROM t WHERE c1 [NOT] IN value_list;

data.subheading: Check if values in a table is NULL or not
data.code: SELECT c1, c2 FROM t WHERE c1 IS [NOT] NULL;
